title: Sir Alex Ferguson reveals how Paolo Maldini's scary dad ended his hopes of signing AC Milan legend
text:
Sport Sir Alex Ferguson reveals how Paolo Maldini's scary dad ended his hopes of signing AC Milan legend The legendary Scot had wanted to take the Italian defender to Old Trafford, but fearsome dad Cesare wasn't going to allow that to happen Share What might have been, eh Fergie? (Photo: AFP/Getty Images/Allsport) Share Get Manchester United FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Football is full of "what might have been" stories. 
Players often narrowly miss out on transfers which could have made or broken their careers, and clubs are often left lamenting the ones that got away as they go on to prove successes elsewhere. 
Sir Alex Ferguson , in his long, trophy-laden career with Manchester United , would have loads of stories like that, and he's revealed one on his trip to New York to promote the International Champions Cup pre-season friendly tournament. 
And it's a good one. He's thinking about nutting a reporter, isn't he? (Photo: REUTERS) 
When Ferguson was joined on stage by AC Milan legend Paolo Maldini - who, with five, has won more European Cup/Champions League titles on his own than United have in their entire history - he was asked if he ever tried to sign the Italian defender. 
And he had. Maldini did this five times (Photo: Getty) Cut him open and he'd bleed red and black (Photo: Getty) 
"I did try," he said, "but when I met his father he was quite formidable, I got a shake of the head. 
"He said: 'My grandfather is Milan, my father is, I am Milan, my sons are Milan. Forget it." 
Maldini's father Cesare played for Milan between 1954 and 1966, before having two spells as manager as well as a stint as Italy boss. He died last year at the age of 84. A scary, scary man (Photo: Reuters) 
Paolo played for Milan for a staggering 25 seasons, and his son Christian captained the under-19 side before leaving the club last summer. 
So it was a good try Sir Alex, but it was never likely to work was it? poll loading Is Sir Alex Ferguson football's greatest ever manager? 2000+ VOTES SO FAR
